Nepal’s ongoing crisis is a struggle between established elites (traditional political parties, bureaucracy, military) and ascendant counter-elites (Gen Z activists, new urban leaders like Balendra Shah). Elite Theory posits that even during revolutionary moments, stable power transitions frequently reinforce existing elite structures or quickly co-opt new actors. My analysis weighs whether Nepal’s elites will allow a transformative outsider like Balen Shah to take the premiership, or whether they will select a compromise or caretaker figure to preserve stability.

Shah himself declined the interim post, and there’s no evidence of him maneuvering—or of a mass movement unified enough to overturn the caretaker arrangement. The only plausible Yes path is a total collapse of the current order, which is not supported by current reporting. Assigning 8% is, frankly, overestimating the likelihood of a second revolutionary pivot in less than three months. The outcome is possible only in the sense that a meteor strike is possible: not zero, but far closer to 1-3% than to 8%.

question_details.title: Who will be the next non-caretaker prime minister of Nepal? (Balendra Shah)
question_details.description:
The Federal: [Who could be Nepal's next prime minister? Here are 5 top contenders](https://thefederal.com/category/international/nepals-next-prime-minister-after-olis-controversial-exit-206263)

> Scuffles were reported among Gen-Z factions backing different contenders outside the Nepal Army headquarters in Kathmandu on Wednesday evening, as talks to pick an interim leader after the violent overthrow of the government extended into the third day.

> KP Sharma Oli resigned as prime minister on Tuesday, leaving the post vacant while the anti-corruption revolt continues without a clear leader.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'Balendra Shah'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question resolves as **Yes** for the individual who, after September 11, 2025 and before January 1, 2026 takes the [oath](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s852) of office and secrecy as the new [Prime Minister of Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Nepal) and wins a vote of confidence in the House of Representatives as required by [section 76](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s795) of the Constitution of Nepal. The question resolves as **No** for everyone else. If none of the listed candidates fulfills the criteria during that time period, then the question resolves as **No** for every option.
question_details.fine_print: This is a Group question, so you do not have to assess probabilities for every option. More options may be added after the question opens, if there is [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) reporting that a particular individual has a material probability of coming the next PM of Nepal.

**After Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, Nepal’s Youth Dismisses Its Political Class**
The article reports that on 8 September 2024 a peaceful gathering in Kathmandu turned into an uprising that toppled Nepal’s political elite, leading to the resignation of Prime Minister Khadga Prasad Sharma Oli.  According to the piece, at least 72 people were killed and 2 000 injured, and preliminary estimates put the damage at 2 to 20 billion euros.  The protests destroyed key state buildings – the Parliament, the Supreme Court, ministries, police stations, hotels and the headquarters of *The Kathmandu Post* – and set fire to the historic Singha Durbar complex.  A Ministry of Health employee lamented, ‘I understand that the youth want change, but it is a mess, all the archives go up in smoke,’ while a transport ministry official said, ‘Do not confuse politicians with the buildings that serve the people.’  The unrest was inspired by earlier youth‑led movements in Indonesia, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, and the article notes that the youth of Nepal, often called ‘Nepo‑kids,’ used TikTok and Discord to organize.  After the army imposed a curfew, the youth elected former Supreme Court chief Sushila Karki as prime minister via a Discord vote, a move described as ‘the first government head elected on Discord.’  The article quotes economist Raghu Bir Bista: ‘Beyond the amounts, Generation Z burned symbols. This explosion reflects the feeling that to change the country, one must topple a gangrenous system.’  It also highlights the country’s economic woes – a GDP per capita of 1 447 € (the lowest in South Asia) and youth unemployment above 20 % – and the frustration that drives many to consider emigration.  The piece concludes that the youth’s rapid political mobilisation, though unprecedented, may lead to a new democratic era if the upcoming 2026 elections bring fresh representatives.

**Prime Minister of Nepal Resigns Amid Massive Protests**
Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli resigned on September 15, 2025, amid violent protests that left at least 19 people dead and hundreds injured. The demonstrations, led by Generation Z, escalated when thousands tried to storm Parliament and government offices, burning former leaders' residences and demanding an end to endemic corruption in Oli's communist regime. Police responded with live fire, tear gas and water cannons, creating chaos in Kathmandu, a curfew was imposed and the army was deployed. Oli, who had been in power since July 2024, stepped down after the assault on his office, citing the failure of communist regimes to respond to popular demands without repression. **Nepal PM Sushila Karki appoints three new ministers for interim cabinet**
On September 15 2025, the Hindustan Times reported that Nepal President Ramchandra Paudel swore in three ministers—Kulman Ghising, Rameshwor Khanal and Om Prakash Aryal—appointed by caretaker Prime Minister Sushila Karki for her newly formed cabinet. The oath ceremony took place at the President's Office, Sheetal Niwas, Maharajgunj, after which all three ministers immediately assumed their posts. Khanal, the former finance secretary, was sworn in as finance minister. The article reports that Nepal is in its most severe political crisis in recent memory after a youth‑led Gen Z movement protested the government’s abrupt ban on 26 major social media platforms, including Facebook, X (formerly Twitter) and YouTube. The ban, intended to enforce registration and regulatory oversight, sparked widespread outrage among young citizens frustrated by corruption, unemployment and lack of political transparency. Violent clashes between demonstrators and security forces have resulted in at least 19 deaths and hundreds of injuries, with protests targeting key state structures and the residences of political leaders. Under mounting pressure, Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli and President Ram Chandra Poudel resigned on 9 September 2025, and Home Minister Ramesh Lekhak also stepped down, citing moral responsibility for the police‑related deaths. Oli reportedly fled the country after his resignation. Although the social media ban was lifted, protests continue, demanding deeper systemic changes beyond restoring digital access. The Nepalese Army issued a statement urging restraint and pledging to safeguard sovereignty, cultural heritage and public property. Under Article 267 of Nepal’s Constitution, the military may be deployed for development work or disaster relief (Clause 4) or during armed rebellion, external threats or severe civil unrest (Clause 6) with approval from the President, the National Security Council and the Cabinet; many analysts argue that invoking Clause 6 would be constitutionally permissible given the scale of violence. As the political vacuum deepens, Balendra Shah, the Mayor of Kathmandu and former musician, has emerged as a leading contender for the premiership, rallying Gen Z activists with his independent, youthful image and calls for reform. However, with Parliament, the Supreme Court and the presidency implicated, a power transition may involve coalition‑led caretaker arrangements until fresh elections or stabilization efforts can be initiated under a consensus‑driven approach, leaving uncertainty about who will assume effective control in the interim.

**Nepal PM Oli resigns amid violent anti-corruption protests by youth & pandemonium on streets**
The Prime Minister of Nepal, K.P. Sharma Oli, resigned on September 9, 2025, according to a statement signed by him that 'he has resigned to pave the way for a constitutional solution to the ongoing crisis', as confirmed by his secretariat (BBC). The resignation came hours after the ban on unregistered social media sites was lifted, a key demand of protesters (BBC). Demonstrators set fire to the private residences of President Ramchandra Paudel and PM Oli in Bohratar and Balkot, party offices and buildings in Janakpur, and broke windows, threw stones, and set buildings ablaze following the deaths of at least 19 protesters on Monday (The Kathmandu Post). **Who is Balendra Shah, Kathmandu mayor who might become Nepal's next PM?**
On September 9 2025, the Daily News and Analysis reported that protests in Nepal over a temporary social media ban and corruption led to at least 19 deaths and more than 300 injuries. Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned, and Kathmandu mayor Balendra Shah, 33, emerged as a potential successor. Shah, a civil engineer and rapper, won the 2022 mayoral election as an independent and has pursued anti‑corruption reforms such as cleaning city streets, improving public schooling and cracking down on tax‑evading institutions. He posted on Facebook: 'My full sympathy is with the youth,' urging leaders not to exploit the agitation for personal or party gains. Time magazine named him among its Top 100 Emerging Leaders and The New York Times praised his transparency and grassroots style of politics. The article portrays Shah as a youth‑backed reformist who could become Nepal’s next prime minister.

summary: All expert forecasters assess the probability of Balendra Shah becoming the next non-caretaker Prime Minister of Nepal before January 1, 2026 as extremely low, generally in the 2–8% range. The consensus emerges across all perspectives—comparative politics, constitutional law, elite theory, coalition theory, and area studies—for several reasons: (1) The current government, led by Sushila Karki, is explicitly described as a caretaker administration with a clear, limited mandate to oversee elections scheduled for March 2026. (2) Constitutional and procedural rules require the non-caretaker PM to command a parliamentary majority and win a vote of confidence, which is considered nearly impossible for an outsider like Shah, who is not an MP and leads no parliamentary party. (3) Shah was initially discussed as a candidate and is a prominent figure with significant Gen-Z and youth support but reportedly declined the interim PM post and has not shown interest in seeking the position in the current period. (4) Historical base rates and precedents in Nepal overwhelmingly favor caretaker/interim governments following crisis, not sudden elevation of outsiders ahead of elections. (5) The elite consensus—including the military, president, and leading protest and political figures—currently supports Karki and the caretaker process as stabilizing and legitimate. (6) While Shah's popularity and the possibility of renewed unrest provide a slim theoretical path to the premiership (in the event of caretaker government failure and a radical, extra-constitutional solution), all current reporting and behaviors suggest institutional continuity is more likely. The only plausible scenario for Shah's rapid elevation would require another acute crisis, mass protest, and a political vacuum, for which there is presently no direct evidence. In conclusion, unless the caretaker government collapses unexpectedly and all other stabilization efforts fail, Shah will not become the next non-caretaker PM before the resolution window closes; he remains a possible future contender, but not within the specified timeframe.
